stuff like that but yeah overall just a giant online gambling company with huge Brands and platforms like FanDuel uh poker stars and more which they claim makes them the number one largest sports betting and igaming operator in the world at over 12 million average monthly players last year because of all this growth flutter has seen staggering Revenue growth in recent years however they are not yet profitable which is usually the case with these type of companies that operate in very heavily saturated markets and thus have to spend most of their profits on advertising and various promos to get people onto their platforms uh over the competition and as a result of all of this saturation flutters Revenue growth is also expected to fall down now into the teens both this year and the next which isn't a great sign at least compared to what they used to put up however margins would be really good if it weren't for all of the advertising and promo spend and that's why you see their forward PE ratio fall from 121% higher than the sector to a 5-year peeg ratio more forward-looking Outlook uh that is actually 44% cheaper than the sector because of all of their expected growth on moving on to purchase number two though we actually have a dividend King in the pharmaceutical giant ABBY ticker symbol abbv which Vanguard scooped up another nearly 10 million shares bringing the stake up to over $31 billion worth now like I said ABY is a dividend King in that they've now increased their dividend for over five decades in a row which still yields 3.6% too and that's always made ABY an attractive dividend stock among investors in fact I actually own the stock myself too however my yield is much higher because I bought it many years ago at some you know much lower prices whereas today the stock has risen to almost a record high still many investors continue to buy the stock today for several reasons for one again that dividend is very attractive but also because ABY has really shown to be a cash generating machine growing their free cash flow from less than 17 billion in 2020 to more than 22 billion last year and that's huge now on the flip side times have been getting more challenging with Rising competition in a saturated Pharmaceuticals Market as well as the patent loss of key drugs including herera which was their uh number one bestselling drug was the number one bestselling drug in the world and as such that free cash flow actually declined by a couple billion last year while Revenue growth has also Fallen to just a mid to low single digit rate and the same goes for their EPS as well and so moving forward I think ABY should be looked at as a bit more of just like a strong cash generating dividend payer than uh something more like a growth type of stock uh and by the way I do feel that the cash will keep coming in I mean this is a company that spends many billions of dollars on R&D every year which results in a lot of innovation a lot of a lot of uh treatments that they can continue developing and putting out there in the market they've got a massive pipeline guys of new drugs and treatments it totals over 75 which is a lot larger than I've seen in a lot of other competitors and I also think that that will help them offset the current struggles and help them maintain their uh their size and their balance and and their dominance and and their cash flow and we're already seeing signs of this with uh for example renok and Sky rezy those two drugs alone are helping make up the losses of Humera as they uh continue to grow larger and larger over time and ab is also investing more heavily into genomic research which I also think will play a huge role in the future of medicine 2o and there's high hopes for that as well and even the valuation isn't as bad as you might expect it to be given the rising stock price I mean you've got a forward p ratio that is 20% cheaper than the sector that's not too bad their PEG ratio is a little higher though at 133% more expensive which illustrates the lack of growth that I talked about but for a giant leader like this to still be trading around these levels I actually think that it's uh pretty reasonable overall anyway it's definitely a stock that I plan to continue holding myself but again you have to keep in mind I got in at much lower prices and I have a much higher dividend yield if I was a new investor into the stock I wouldn't be buying it I I would actually prefer uh something else like fizer or Bristol Meers squib who are also in Pharmaceuticals biotechs but they have cheaper valuations and they have much higher dividend yields at the moment like double the yields I think right now so I would prefer that but because I do already own the stock I guess I have to rank that will have her bring us now though to the third purchase of the list and we have another stock here that I also own and that is in broadcom ticker symbol avgo which Vanguard increase by another 3% bringing the stake up to almost $60 billion and worth over 1% of the overall portfolio now we have actually covered broadcom last week too as a stock that Steve Cohen is buying so I'll keep this short into the point here but basically broadcom has been rising a lot this year that's thanks to strong earnings and especially their advancements in AI which led to Bank of America even calling them their top two AI pick how crazy is that for their work in developing custom AI chips for business saying that the company could even potentially join the trillionaires Club in the future alongside other Tech giants like Google Amazon Apple meta Microsoft and Nvidia to which Goldman Sachs added that along with Nvidia they see broadcom as a critical piece to the ongoing AI infrastructure buildout that's wow on top of these positives though broadcom also recently split their stock which usually leads to a boost as it's more easily accessible to smaller investors and in total the stock has now risen to a record high and is up over 23% over the past decade and yet valuation wise it's actually not super crazy not as crazy as you would think it'be and that's thanks to their earnings growth as their PEG ratio is only less than 10% higher than the sector I do feel that the stock has already risen by too much for me though to be buying significantly more at these prices but even here I still think that you get a very solid business with strong financials strong future promise in AI cloudcomputing cyber security and other Technologies on the heels of a fantastic acquisition of VMware and you even get a nice little dividend too with some solid growth metrics on it it so I'll rank them at number two I'm going to push everything else down one spot to fit it in

company that does well over half a trillion dollars in revenue and is still somehow growing at a double digit rate is just way too good to pass up on and even though their profits are technically you know in the tens of billions of dollars there's still nothing compared to the size of their sales by comparison which is why the valuation appears to be rich at first glance however once they actually start caring about profits that valuation I think will come down I think people will regret not only the stock and for it to only be 133% higher than the sector on a PEG ratio and actually 77% cheaper than their 5-year average on PE I just think Amazon is a sleeper here I know it sounds crazy right but I think it's a bit of a sleeper that people dismiss because of how much the stock has already climbed but when I just sit back and think about how dominant this company has become here to the point where I feel like pretty much everyone I know has a Prime membership at this point and I don't ever see them losing ground there either I just think that's going to keep climbing because they just add so much value to these memberships with having virtually anything you want and anything you need right at your doorstep within like one to two days usually at and and also at much lower prices than most brick and mortar you know stores Alternatives out there plus you know you get video streaming you get music there's just so much here and when I look at the convenience of it all I just think most people are going to continue being willing to pay for Prime they're not going to get rid of it I don't think I I think they have a lot of pricing power actually and uh having that giant pool of users I think is just going to continue to be super valuable to them not to mention all the other stuff they do like you know the cloud computing the digital advertising the investments in EVs and gaming and even Pharmaceuticals I mean I just think the genie is out of the bottle at this point and you're not getting it back in there Amazon is in my opinion too big to fail at this point and not just that but it's going to continue to get even larger over time and most importantly I think it's going to become very profitable too as they kind of start to dominate the world as weird as that sounds but uh hey if that's going to happen why fight it I think it's a stock that is worth
